newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil says ready for arbitration in WTO auto row.
newsitem.headline: Brazil says ready for arbitration in WTO auto row.

text.p: Brazil said Wednesday it is prepared to go to arbitration to fend off complaints before the World Trade Organisation (WTO) that its car import rules are unfair to trading partners.
"The government is ready for talks. We are ready to defend the Brazilian auto regime in arbitration," Sergio Amaral, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's chief spokesman, told reporters.
Local newspapers reported Wednesday that the European Union (EU) was set to ask the WTO to create a dispute panel to look into Brazil's automotive regime.

EU officials, who this week have been meeting Brazilian representatives in Geneva, were not convinced by Brazil's offer to raise its car import quotas for the EU to 12,000 cars a year from 10,000 and make small changes in its rules, they said.
"We are very determined to go ahead with a request for a WTO panel against the automotive regime," O Globo quoted an unnamed EU official as saying.
"I don't say its 100 percent because the decision has not been taken yet. But we concluded Brazil has limited flexibility to negotiate," the official added.
The dispute has dragged on since last year, when Japan, the United States, the EU and other leading carmakers filed complaints with the WTO seeking formal consultation over Brasilia's car rules.

Amaral on Wednesday sought to play down concerns about the growing number of trade complaints against Brazil, saying it was the natural result of the country's own increased participation in international trade.
"As Brazil enters more into the international market, the number of complaints rise," he said. "You should see how many complaints there are against the United States."
